node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text: For most of 2020 the theory that covid-19 leaked from a Chinese lab was dismissed as unlikely. In the past few months it has gained currency. Our experts explain why. Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: Did covid-19 leak from a Chinese lab?

node.text: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies set out to upend the financial order and replace conventional money. Bitcoin has certainly disrupted the global financial system, but can it ever live up to the hype? Cover credit: Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images

Jair Bolsonaro’s actions do not just threaten Brazilian democracy—they have also endangered one of the world’s most important natural resources.

node.text: Myanmar is on the brink of collapse. Its armed forces are continuing a brutal crackdown—arresting, torturing and killing protesters—as Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s de-facto leader, is detained. Our experts answer your questions. Cover image: STR/ Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 29, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Leaders A crackdown on the online-education business marks a turning-point China may have miscalculated'.

node.text:
When it comes to teaching schoolchildren, no one should get rich. So goes the logic of the Chinese government.⁠
⁠
The education-technology industry is the latest victim of China’s regulatory clampdown, joining Alibaba, Tencent and Didi Global.⁠
⁠
New regulations bar any company that teaches subjects on the school curriculum from listing abroad, having foreign investors or making profits.⁠
⁠
The news startled markets. It signalled that any investment, even in an onshore non-tech firm, is now at risk from arbitrary rule changes.⁠
⁠
But China’s policy brass may have miscalculated. To read what this regulatory high-handedness means for its Chinese tech, click on the link in our bio.

node.text:
Robinhood went public today via its retail investors. The trading app ushered in a direct-to-retail-investors approach that has become widespread, yet amidst its raging success, uncertainties loom.⁠
⁠
On our “Money Talks” podcast, finance correspondent Alice Fulwood explains why Robinhood’s IPO was so unusual, and tells us why some regulators and commentators are uneasy about the platform.⁠
⁠
Also on the podcast, as food prices soar, big agriculture is having a field day. And what lessons from the history books could help us in this new age of central banking?⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to listen to “Money Talks” in full

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and text that says 'United States America's vaccination woes cannot be blamed only on politics MY BODY MYCHOICE'.

node.text:
Throughout the United States covid-19 is spreading rapidly, mostly owing to the highly contagious Delta variant.⁠
⁠
Prominent Republican leaders have long politicised the jab and other covid-19 prevention methods, such as masks and social distancing. But politics isn’t the only problem.⁠
⁠
The barrage of vaccine scepticism would have been much less effective had people been equipped with a better understanding of health and science. ⁠
⁠
In the long term, education and trusted information—along with access to better health care—will be vital in overcoming disinformation, raising vaccination rates and improving America’s overall health.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read more on why America’s covid cases are rising and what’s to blame.⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Proteinotopia Understanding how proteins fold could open up almost limitless vistas ಪಲ'.

node.text:
In a wonderful and ancient mechanism called the ribosome, words—in the form of messages stored in DNA—are translated into flesh, in the form of proteins.⁠
⁠
The actions of proteins lie behind all the strengths and frailties of body and mind. Both their manipulation and their mass production are fundamental to modern pharmacology.⁠
⁠
Therefore understanding them—and how they fold themselves up into specific forms, a process which produces all manner of kinks, twists, swirls, sheets and cavities—is crucial to medicine, agriculture and even replacing petrochemicals. ⁠
⁠
AlphaFold, a very elegant piece of software developed by DeepMind, has learned to make predictions of protein shapes using just the amino-acid sequences of their very bendy backbones. ⁠
⁠
To learn how software such as AlphaFold will usher in a new era of knowledge about proteins and their potential applications, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @danieliev

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Why people reject jabs The How will China's tech bashing go? Economist Proteinotopia: biological orıgamı Robinhood and merry mob JULY31ST-AUGUST6TH2021 Dashed hopes Emerging markets' growth problem'.

node.text:
At the start of the century, developing economies were a source of unbounded optimism and fierce ambition.⁠
⁠
Today South Africa is reeling from an insurrection, Colombia has suffered violent protests and Tunisia faces a constitutional crisis. ⁠
⁠
Illiberal government is in fashion. This partly reflects covid-19, which has exposed and exploited vulnerabilities. ⁠
⁠
Yet the despair and chaos threaten to exacerbate a profound economic problem: many poor and middle-income countries are losing the knack of catching up with the richest ones.⁠
⁠
But giving up now would be a grave error. Click the link in our bio to read why a strategy of openness is the key to better times.⁠
⁠
Cover: @guillemcasasus

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 4 people and text that says 'United States Republican delusion about the Capitol riot hits a dangerous dang new low'.

node.text:
This week four visibly traumatised police officers told a congressional inquiry of a mortal fight against Donald Trump’s supporters during the Capitol riot—and the former president’s party shrugged.⁠
⁠
Hollywood action flicks have been less dramatic than the scenes they outlined during the hearing into the events of January 6th.⁠
⁠
Among the officers was an Iraq veteran who spoke of a “medieval battle”. Another said he was dragged through the mob, electrocuted until he suffered a heart attack, then beaten unconscious.⁠
⁠
And yet most House Republicans are now misrepresenting or wishing away the violence, to try to minimise Mr Trump’s hand in the events. Most Republican voters believe there has already been too much focus on the insurrection, and that Joe Biden was chiefly to blame for it⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why denialism of this kind is familiar to the Republican Party—yet, on this scale and issue, also unprecedented.⁠
⁠
Credit: DPA

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Which is the strongest Olympic team of all time? Greece Share of Olympic medals won, top three teams at each games,% Host nation United States WWI WWII Japan 80 Soviet Union 60 China 40 1896 1908 20 20 36 52 68 84 0 2000 Sources: Gracenote; International Olympic Committee; Sports reference; "The Complete Book of the Olympics", Wallechinsky & Loucky 2020 forecast The Economist'.

node.text:
What are the key ingredients to dominating the Olympics? Clue: home advantage is one way to strike gold.⁠
⁠
Since the first modern Olympic games in Athens in 1896, the country with home advantage has won the most medals ten times but times are changing. America is expected to win the most medals—as it has done in the previous six Olympiads.⁠
⁠
However, contemporary Olympic teams now need to be exceptional across a much wider range of disciplines, from badminton to beach volleyball, surfing to sport climbing. ⁠
⁠
With more medals up for grabs than ever, fielding the strongest team of Olympians requires more than just home advantage now. Tap the link in our bio to find out what makes the strongest Olympic team.⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021. May be an image of tree, outdoors and text that says 'Middle East & Africa Dry and disorderly: climate change is leaving parts of the region parched'.

node.text:
In the neighbourhood of Algiers, Algeria's capital, where the presidential palace and foreign embassies are located, some think the water pressure has increased of late.⁠
⁠
In the city's suburbs, it is a different story. Taps have been dry for days. ⁠
⁠
Algeria is not the only country that is suffering—across the Middle East and north Africa, water shortages and high temperatures are common. ⁠
⁠
The lack of water has led to unrest: protests have erupted in Iraq, Sudan and Yemen. In Iran, two protesters were shot dead last week.⁠
⁠
Water is sometimes used as a weapon. It could even become the main cause of future conflicts. ⁠
⁠
For most of the region the trend is towards a drier, hotter, more miserable future. Some governments are dealing with the problem. But tap the link in our bio to read how others are making it worse.⁠
⁠
Credit: Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021. May be an image of cat and text that says 'Finance & economics Can foreign venture capitalists make good money from Indian tech? ma'.

node.text:
Nothing speaks of potential quite like India’s tech scene, with its vast, young, tech-savvy population. But on closer inspection, does it live up to the billing?⁠
⁠
A flood of foreign money is washing into the industry, and no venture­-capital story is quite as seductive as this one.⁠
⁠
The burgeoning interest in India owes a lot to the diminishing appeal of China, whose tech firms are facing a regulatory backlash.⁠
⁠
However, the numbers just don’t add up. Tap the link in our bio to find out why Indian tech's formula for success cannot simply be copied across from America or China.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @satillustration

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
The rush of cities interested in hosting the Olympics has slowed to a trickle, and voters are quickly going off the idea.⁠
⁠
The most common gripe is cost, but this year the risk to public safety with covid-19 cases rising is a factor, too. ⁠
⁠
The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has been changed the bidding process. Cities are no longer forced to put together proposals costing tens of millions of dollars.⁠
⁠
The new process gives more control to the IOC. This is likely to result in fewer costly mistakes but also more accusations of partiality.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read whether the IOC’s changes would rekindle an interest in playing host once again. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021.

node.text:
Civil partnerships gave gay couples in Britain the same rights as marriage gave straight couples. Soon after they were introduced, in 2004, straight people wanted to get them too. ⁠
⁠
After a long campaign to change the law, straight couples in Britain are now able to get civil partnerships.⁠
⁠
They appeal to couples who want a modern, equal partnership, clean of assumptions about what a marriage should be. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read why @1843mag thinks we should raise a toast to this modern form of marriage.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Mari Fouz

node.text:
Today marks the 70th anniversary of the United Nations’ refugee convention, a landmark treaty that established the obligations that countries have to people fleeing persecution. ⁠
⁠
It has become perhaps the least popular treaty in the rich world. ⁠
⁠
The world is creating more and more refugees, even as fewer and fewer governments have the appetite to protect them. ⁠
⁠
“Countries face a difficult obligation to winnow out who’s a genuine refugee,” our correspondent tells “The Intelligence”. ⁠
⁠
Part of the challenge they face is that a lot of people on the move are economic migrants. Many who arrive in Europe or at the southern borders of the United States are genuinely fleeing persecution, and some are looking for a better life.⁠
⁠
The world has changed a lot since the treaty was agreed in 1951. Is it still fit for purpose? Our correspondent says not. To find out why, tap the link in our bio to listen to the podcast.
